body_html:
I can't speak to that specific model, but in the general case you have to have the actual GraphDef which defines the model topology (this may be created by a python script somewhere?). Then you can run freeze_graph.py on it to combine it with the checkpoint file, which embeds all the trained weights inside it as constant ops so that it can easily be loaded on mobile.

Additionally, you can then run optimize_for_inference to strip out unused ops that may not be supported on Android.
body_text:
I can't speak to that specific model, but in the general case you have to have the actual GraphDef which defines the model topology (this may be created by a python script somewhere?). Then you can run freeze_graph.py on it to combine it with the checkpoint file, which embeds all the trained weights inside it as constant ops so that it can easily be loaded on mobile.
Additionally, you can then run optimize_for_inference to strip out unused ops that may not be supported on Android.
body:
I can't speak to that specific model, but in the general case you have to have the actual GraphDef which defines the model topology (this may be created by a python script somewhere?). Then you can run [freeze_graph.py](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/python/tools/freeze_graph.py) on it to combine it with the checkpoint file, which embeds all the trained weights inside it as constant ops so that it can easily be loaded on mobile.

Additionally, you can then run [optimize_for_inference](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/python/tools/optimize_for_inference.py) to strip out unused ops that may not be supported on Android.
